Hunters must expect to see bears

With Montana's bow hunting, which opens Sept. 5, and upland game bird seasons, which opened Sept. 1, remember that slow moving, quiet or game-calling, scented and camouflaged hunters will soon be sharing the landscape with the state's even stealthier bears that may be stalking similar prey.

Given the uncertainty of where and when these dispersing bears might show up, hunters should:

- carry bear spray, be prepared and know how to use it
- hunt with a partner and let someone else know your plans
- get harvested big game out of the woods quickly
upon returning to a site where harvested game is left unattended, study the site at a distance for any movement or changes and signal your approach by making plenty of noise
- never attempt to frighten or haze a bear from a carcass
- contact FWP if a bear has consumed a carcass or covered it with debris rendering it unsalvageable
Photo: Donny.MT.406

post_text:
Is there such thing as Shiras moose?
100 years ago, moose in the US Rockies were given their own name, “Shiras moose”, a unique subspecies. Still today, moose in this region are notably smaller compared to their largest relatives in Alaska, and are tracked separately in trophy records. However, FWP biologists recently joined other western states and provinces from Colorado to Alaska and used hunter-provided tissue samples to test if Shiras moose are genetically distinct. In short, their results indicated they likely are not! Genetically speaking, moose across western North America were found to all be quite closely related (moreso than other species like deer or caribou), and any differences more likely the result of climate- or habitat-relationships than genetic distinctions. In short, across their western range from Colorado to Alaska, “a moose is a moose.”

Learn more at https://buff.ly/3bnqhma #FWPWildTalkThursday

A permanent hoot owl restriction adopted by the commission last year for a portion of the lower Madison River will go into effect today, July 15.

The restriction will apply to the stretch of the river from the Bureau of Land Management’s Warm Springs Boat Launch to the confluence with the Jefferson River. This annual closure will be in effect from July 15 through Aug. 15 every year, starting in 2020.

Hoot owl restrictions prohibit fishing each day between 2 p.m. and midnight. Restrictions of this nature are enacted to protect fish, such as trout, which become more susceptible to disease and mortality when high water temperatures combine with additional stressors.

The Montana Fish & Wildlife Commission approved this permanent yearly restriction for the Madison River on Oct. 17, 2019, as part of an update to fishing regulations.

Montana has enjoyed a fairly wet spring and early summer, but fire season in Montana is just around the corner. This means it’s everyone’s responsibility to be careful with fire and any potential sources of ignition. Fireworks are illegal on all state and federal land in Montana, including all FWP fishing access sites, wildlife management areas and other sites.

Anyone using fireworks on FWP lands may be charged with a misdemeanor that can result in a fine up to $500.

Has Catch-and-Release Gone Overboard?
The case for harvesting trout - By Tom Dickson featured in Montana Outdoors Magazine

The fish leapt, made a strong run upstream, leapt again, then
finally submitted as I led it into the shallows next to an island on the Missouri River upstream from Craig. Kneeling in the water, I cradled the trout in my hands and slipped the hook free. Then, looking to make sure no one was watching, I bashed the 19-inch rainbow in the head with a softball-size rock.

Killing that big, beautiful fish was perfectly legal and biologically justifiable. But to a growing number of anglers, what I’d done ought to be a hangin’ offense. To continue reading visit https://buff.ly/3czgati

Orphaned grizzly cubs going to Bearizona Wildlife Park

Working jointly, staff from Montana Fish Wildlife & Parks and the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service found a home for three grizzly bear cubs that were orphaned last month. The cubs will be placed at Bearizona Wildlife Park, located in Williams, AZ. This 158-acre facility is accredited by the Zoological Association of America and is home to 39 black bears and many other species of North American wildlife. The wildlife park receives more than 400,000 visitors annually and educates the public on the importance of conservation and wildlife management.

The cubs came from a female that was involved in a surprise encounter with a hiker near Dupuyer. The female was euthanized on April 9 by FWP staff after she was shot and injured by a hiker. At the time, it wasn’t clear how many cubs she had, though it was thought she had at least one.

To read more visit https://buff.ly/2THF6IK

White-tailed deer in Gallatin County suspected positive for CWD

Initial test results have identified a white-tailed buck deer in Gallatin County as being suspect for carrying chronic wasting disease.

The deer was euthanized earlier this month in the Springhill area of north Bozeman after displaying several classic symptoms of the disease.

This case is the first detection of CWD in Gallatin County. CWD was first detected in Montana in 2017 and is known to exist along the state’s southern and northern borders, as well as in neighboring states and provinces. The first detection of CWD in southwest Montana was in December near Sheridan.

CWD is a fatal disease affecting the nervous system of deer, elk and moose. Transmission most commonly occurs through direct contact between animals. Carcasses and bodily fluids of infected animals can also be sources of infection for other cervids that come into contact with them.

To read more visit https://buff.ly/3bHZzmU

FWP offering free online courses for hunter and bowhunter education students

The COVID-19 pandemic is changing so many parts of life in Montana this year – hunter and bowhunter education is no different. In response to social distancing requirements and restrictions on group gatherings, FWP is turning to online courses for all students this year only.

The online courses and mandatory field days have been available to adults for a tuition fee of $25 for hunter education and $30 for bowhunter education. The in-person courses have always been, and will remain, free. However, since the in-person options aren’t feasible under Phases 1 and 2 of Gov. Steve Bullock’s Reopening the Big Sky plan, FWP will cover the online tuition fees for all Montana residents until the state reaches Phase 3 of the plan and in-person hunter and bowhunter education courses are available once again.

The online courses will be available May 12 to Montana residents who are at least the age of 12 by Jan. 16, 2021.

To read more visit https://buff.ly/3cqGoPN

Attractants include pet food, bird feeders, garbage, livestock supplements and fruit trees.There are many ways to store attractants, including inside hard sided buildings, sheds, or surrounding them with electric fences. The future of grizzly bears is in the hands of the people who live, work and recreate in bear habitat.

The success of grizzly bear recovery in the lower 48 states is due to state, federal and private efforts. Without the belief that this iconic species was important, it possibly would have been lost to us all. After decades of effort from landowners, interest groups and agencies, increase in grizzly numbers and distribution has exceeded everyone’s expectations. With success came challenges as human activities across a broad landscape and bears finding places to roam have, in some cases, run into conflict. Traditional ranching and farming, small communities and folks recreating are finding bears in places they haven’t in generations. This has meant change to their normal thinking and operations on the landscape of western to central Montana as well as Wyoming and Idaho.

Hi Torrey here, there is certainly a lot we know about beavers, but of course there is also a lot we don’t know. A couple of important pieces of needed knowledge are dispersal distances in mountainous Montana and the types of habitats beavers look for when they are trying to start a brand new colony. This information is useful when folks want to try and encourage beavers to settle in a new area where they can do a lot of good work!

The need for this basic dispersal and settlement information spurred my graduate research, where we radio-marked young beavers and followed them as they struck out on their own to establish a territory and get to being busy. You can see the little yellow transmitter attached to the beaver’s tail in the photo. It was an incredibly fun and challenging project, and we learned a lot about how young beavers become adult beavers in the real world. #tuesdayswithtorrey Photo: Nathaniel Pehl

Restrictions on Canyon Ferry reservoir boat launches have been removed allowing all boaters to access all boat ramps this year. Montana Fish, Wildlife & Parks sought to remove the launch restrictions after three years of testing resulted in no detections of invasive quagga or zebra mussels.

The discovery of invasive mussel larvae in Tiber reservoir and a suspect detection of Canyon Ferry reservoir prompted restrictions on boating access in 2017. Boaters were required to launch at designated boat ramps and go through a decontamination station when exiting the water.

Regional guidelines allow for the delisting of a suspect waterbody and the removal of the mandatory exit inspections if three years of monitoring show no detections of invasive mussels.

Restrictions on Tiber Reservoir will remain in place for at least two more years.To learn more visit https://buff.ly/2uYiqL5

post_text: FWP biologists, game wardens, and park rangers converged on Wild Horse Island February 3 and 4 to conduct health assessments on bighorn sheep. The main objectives were to analyze genetic diversity and check for signs of pneumonia, an epidemic among western bighorn sheep populations. Ewes also received ultrasounds on their hips. With these images, biologists were able to measure fat thickness, which is used to determine fertility health. Thanks to the hard work and dedication of 13 FWP employees, including an on-site veterinarian, and a 3-man helicopter crew, 26 sheep were humanely captured, checked, and released on Wild Horse Island. By conducting these periodic health checks, FWP is able maintain a healthy herd and a healthy island ecosystem.

Landowners have until March 16 to submit applications to FWP for enrollment in the Unlocking Public Lands Program to be eligible for up to $3,000 in tax credits.

The Unlocking Public Lands program is designed to provide recreational public access to state or federal land where no legal public access currently exists.

In exchange for access across the private lands, landowners will receive a tax credit in the amount of $750 per agreement and up to a maximum of $3,000 tax credit per year. Landowners decide how the public may cross their private property and may limit access to foot traffic only.

While Montana contains nearly 29 million acres of public land, much of this land requires landowner permission to cross private land to reach the adjoining state or federal land.

Application form and more information can be found at https://buff.ly/30WjCKu.

#stuffbeaversdo
It has been approximately one year since I started doing Tuesdays with Torrey and I have truly enjoyed it. I think social media gets a bad rap these days and seeing people comment with photos and stories and snippets of their wildlife encounters has been a lot of fun and reminded me why I still like this platform.

To celebrate the approximately one-year anniversary I would now like to introduce you to my absolute tippy-top favorite animal… Castor canadensis. I am forced to use the Latin name here because no matter how much we all wish it weren’t so, the internet is the internet. The North American Beaver (Castor canadensis) is one of the most fascinating and important animals in the entire northern hemisphere, and over the coming weeks I want to take you on a brief (ha!) tour of the industrious beavers and all their workings. Along the way, I will sprinkle in many more examples of Montana’s wealth of nongame wildlife, but with a special focus on those species beavers can directly or indirectly benefit, which is a lot of species. Join me! #TuesdayswithTorrey

New Walleye and Perch Regulations Now in Effect on Holter Reservoir

Anglers are reminded of a regulation change that began Jan. 1 for walleye and perch fishing at Holter Reservoir south of Great Falls.

Yellow perch limits are now 25 daily and in possession. Walleye limits are now five daily, only one larger than 25 inches; and the possession limit is twice the daily limit.

The changes will be listed in the new fishing regulations, which will be out in time for the new license year that begins March 1.

Governor’s Grizzly Bear Advisory Council to Meet in Polson

The advisory council, made up of 18 citizens from across Montana, will gather Jan. 14-15, at the KwaTaqnuk Resort in Polson. The meeting will start at 8 a.m. on Jan. 14 and 9:30 a.m. on Jan. 15. The meetings are open to the public and opportunities for public engagement will be available both days. The public is also encouraged to provide input to council members online at fwp.mt.gov/gbac.

Additional meetings will be held across the state to provide more people the opportunity to interact with the council.

All year round there are 20+ different species of small mammals living important and fascinating lives just under your feet. If we were able to fully observe their world, we would find drama that would rival the wolves and elk of Yellowstone! #TuesdayswithTorrey

Day 9 of Fishmas: 9 species of native suckers

From cold, clear streams to large, turbid rivers, suckers (family Catostomidae) play an important role throughout Montana’s aquatic ecosystems. Nine species are native to the state, ranging in size from the 4-in. Mountain Sucker all the way up to the 43-in. and nearly 70-lbs. Bigmouth Buffalo. Compared to other groups of fishes, suckers are relatively long-lived (typically with an 8-16 year lifespan); notably though, Blue Sucker have been aged beyond 40-years and some Bigmouth Buffalo have been found to reach 112-years. While the name might imply gullible, you can bet these wise wizards of the wild have seen a thing or two in their day.

Day 8- 008 Kokanee salmon

If you see the number 008 written on a data sheet, it’s from a biologist sampling fish in one of Montana’s 39 waterbodies that contain the elusive kokanee salmon. In MT, biologists use 156 unique species codes and abbreviations when enumerating fish. Kokanee (or “KOK”) are a landlocked form of sockeye salmon that primarily feed on zooplankton (tiny crustaceans) suspended in the water column. Anglers target kokanee in open water by trolling a variety of lures that look nothing like their food source, essentially antagonizing the fish to bite. KOK typically live 3-4 years before morphologically changing and donning the classic bright red colors in the fall, looking for a place to spawn. A smoked delicacy, kokanee are prized table fare for even the pickiest critic.

Pictures and description are from our Pollution Control Biologist, and kokanee angling expert, Trevor Selch!

Day 4 of Fishmas

There are four species of catfish (family Ictaluridae) found in Montana; two native species (Channel Catfish and Stonecat), and two nonnative species (Black Bullhead and Yellow Bullhead). Catfishes are notably distinct in having barbels (often called whiskers) and an adipose fin (the fleshy appendage also found on trout, salmon, and whitefish)…although, the adipose fin of a Stonecat isn’t very apparent, as it is fused with the caudal fin. While Channel Catfish is by far the largest species of this group (in Montana growing in excess of 41” and 34#), all four species are readily caught on hook-and-line. #fishmas

Day 3 of Fishmas - 3 Walleye Spine Cross-Sections

Fish from the Perch Family (e.g., sauger, yellow perch, walleye) have dorsal fins which contain hard, pokey structures known as spines. Biologists can remove these spines, take a thin slice, and shine light through these slices to look at the tree-ring-like bands known as annuli. Periods of slow growth (winter) are narrow and fast growth (summer) are wide and transparent. So, you can tell how old a walleye, for example, is by counting the number of observed dark bands as you work outward from the center of each spine cross-section.

How old are these three walleye in the photo on the left? First person to answer correctly wins an FWP Buff.

Day 2 of Fishmas - Otoliths from Freshwater Drum

Otoliths are “ear stones”, or bony structures found in the inner ear of most fish. These bones help fish with hearing and balance. They record the history of fish in layers, and as a result, they can be used to age a fish and even help understand a fish’s diet and movements between habitats over its lifetime. Freshwater drum have some of the largest otoliths of any freshwater fish because they communicate with each other, especially during spawning. After you filet a drum for its wonderful, sweet, and flaky white flesh, you can remove these structures as a trophy to remember your catch and your meal. Think of them like little elk ivories, and like ivories, you can make them into beautiful jewelry! #FishMT #Fishmas

post_text: Tony, a hunter from Great Falls won the lottery in the hunting world and drew a 2019 deer super tag. Tony saw one heck of a buck during late summer in full velvet, he hoped they would meet again during season. Tony spent almost 40 days in the field scouting, hiking, and hunting determined to fill his super tag and dreaming of still finding that August buck. It came to closing day and he hadn't lost hope. Finally at 4:42 pm at the very end of the season, before the sun set over the hills, Tony and the buck met again. The countless hours in the field came down to that moment, and it was nothing but worth it. The persistence and determination paid off. "Thanks for making it possible to win these. I never knew anyone to win one of these until I did. What an experience, this is real and anyone can get it," said Tony. #mymontanahunt

Happy #FisheriesFriday today we will discuss life after hatch at a hatchery.

The newly hatched fish have a yolk sac from which they gain their nutrients until the yolk sac is absorbed. At the end of that period the fish are ready to eat. Fish are fed a steady diet of protein, fat and other nutrients that are essential to fish survival and growth. Fish are fed daily and monitored by hatchery employees to ensure fish health. When fish reach the requested size (determined by a fisheries biologist), they are stocked into bodies of water throughout the state. There are several ways to stock fish in Montana waters: boat, truck, plane, helicopter, backpack and pack horses. #FisheriesFriday

You never quite know where a bat will be…

Bats are well known for showing up in caves, mines, spooky old buildings, and whenever a vampire enters the room. But bats are also hanging out (as it were) in lots of places you wouldn’t expect. In fact, every time you are hopping through a mountainous boulder field, navigating through a forest, or crossing a bridge, you are likely passing by bats tucked into the warm and cozy cracks and crevices of the natural (and sometimes unnatural) world. This photo was taken back in July in the foothills near Helena. Deep in that diagonal crack in the middle of the photo we discovered a lone little bat known as the western small-footed myotis. During the day, bats seek out these types of crevices because they are warm, dark, and offer some protection from predators. The perfect place to sleep off a busy night out. When night returns again, they pour out from the nooks and crannies of landscape to begin their nightly raid on flying insects.#TuesdayswithTorrey

While Rainbow Trout typically spawn in the spring, artificial selection of late-spawning fish over years and years has helped create the Arlee strain. By spawning fish in the fall, the hatchery can better meet the needs of the biologists and provide fish to stock out earlier in the year.

The process of spawning (shown here) starts with close monitoring of the fish to ensure peak spawning is captured. Fish in raceways are crowded down using a screen and are separated by sex. Time to put gloves on…that water is pretty chilly (~48F)! Fish are placed in an anesthetic bath and then milt is collected from males and eggs are collected by females; first by using air to extract eggs, and then by hand to get any remaining. Eggs and milt are then combined and mixed gently for 3-minutes. The fertilized eggs are then rinsed to water-harden the eggs and to remove any impurities. Finally, eggs are enumerated and are readied to incubate to eye-up stage at 20-days and then hatch at 30-days. Fish will be held until 4-inches and kicked out at some point during the summer. #FisheriesFriday
